title.narrative: Markets & Value Chains in Agriculture Liberia

description.narrative: Stöd till utveckling av marknader och värdekedjor i utvalda delsektorer inom jordbruket, genom tillämpning av en 'making-markets-work-for-the-poor'-ansats.
Support to development of markets and value chains within selected agricultural sub-sectors, adopting a 'making-markets-work-for-the-poor' (M4P) approach.

tag.narrative: 17.17 - Encourage and promote effective public, public-private and civil society partnerships, building on the experience and resourcing strategies of partnerships
17.17 - Encourage and promote effective public, public-private and civil society partnerships, building on the experience and resourcing strategies of partnerships.

2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.

2.a - Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in particular least developed countries.

2.a - Öka investeringarna, bland annat genom stärkt internationellt samarbete, i infrastruktur på landsbygden, forsknings- och rådgivningstjänster för jordbruket, teknikutveckling samt genbanker för växter och husdjur i syfte att öka jordbrukets produktionskapacitet i utvecklingsländerna, i synnerhet de minst utvecklade länderna.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
8.2 - Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value added and labour-intensive sectors.
8.2 - Uppnå högre ekonomisk produktivitet genom diversifiering, teknisk uppgradering och innovation, bland annat genom att fokusera på sektorer med högt förädlingsvärde och hög arbetsintensitet.
8.6 - By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.
8.6 - Till 2020 väsentligt minska den andel ungdomar som varken arbetar eller studerar.

title.narrative: GROW markets and value chains agreement
GROW markets and value chains monitoring consultant agreement amendment
GROW markets and value chains decision on contribution

description.narrative: GROW’s impact has increased significantly in the last years. This is expected in successful MSD programmes where the first years are focused on establishing strategies, building initial relationships, and testing hypotheses while the later years are focused on scaling up successful interventions and approaches through a wider reach of partners. It is also expected that this impact trajectory will continue after the close of a market development programme owed to commercially-viable approaches and realignment of market incentives. This is also the case for GROW. In particular, GROW has gained significant impact traction within the Cocoa and Vegetables sectors over the last years that account for the bulk of the impact owed to GROW. Aggregated results in relation to objectives for March 2020 (from annual report)1. Market Actors: GROW and its private sector partners engaged with total of 188 different market actors in 2019 compared to 162 in 2018. This represents 104% of the target. In the Cocoa sector, GROW engaged more buyers and cooperatives whilst in the Vegetables sector, GROW engaged six new agro-dealers. 2. Business Innovations: GROW has supported a total of 98 business innovations (114% of target). This includes strengthening the relationship between exporters (buyers) and cooperatives and also supporting farmers to adopt to good agriculture practices (GAP) through introduction of various competitions. In the Vegetables sector, GROW introduced the use of the sales agent model with the aim to upskill more farmers on GAP, proper use and benefits of agro-inputs as well as to facilitate sales of agro-inputs. 3. Investment Leveraged: GROW's private and public sector partners have invested a total of USD 2.98M. The Cocoa sector contributes to 47% of total investment leveraged which includes investment in warehouse, transportation, human resources and pre-financing for cocoa purchase. The Vegetables sector contributes to 28% of investment leveraged which includes investment in set up of a new distributor, shop expansion and purchase of additional. The Rubber sector contributes to total investment leveraged of 23%, the majority of which has been the cost involved in RSS processing facility set-up, whilst the agro- processing sector contributes to 2%. 4. Total number of households with access to new opportunities: A total of 41,000 households had access to new opportunities such as training on GAP in cocoa farming and vegetable farming, grade-differentiated pricing system, access to reliable markets, and access to quality production inputs. 5. Total number of households adopting to new opportunities: A total of 36,500 households adopted new opportunities facilitated through GROW's private sector. This represents 118% of the target. The Cocoa sector contributes to 59% of this, followed by the Vegetables sector (39%). 6. Total number of households with positive net attributable income change: A total of 29,100 households have benefited through positive net attributable income change in 2019 compared to 17,000 in 2018. This represents 116% of target and 71% increase from last year. The Cocoa sector contributes to 62% of these achievements as cocoa farmers have benefited from increased yield, better quality cocoa and higher prices for cocoa. The Vegetables sector contributes to 35% of this as vegetable farmers have also benefited from increased yield and sales. 7. Full time equivalent (FTE) Jobs created: Close to 2,000 additional jobs were created in 2019 taking total cumulative FTE jobs to 2,710. This represents 244% of its targets. It is worth noting that 93% of additional FTE jobs were created at the farm labor level whilst the remaining 7% were created at partner level (factory or processing staff). 8. Total Net Attributable Income Change (NAIC): GROW has contributed to total net attributable income change of USD 7.98 Million (compared to USD 4,4 Million the previous year). This represents 67% of the targets. 90% of the NAIC is derived from increased yield and sales and the remaining 10% is from FTE jobs. Increased income per cocoa farming household stands at USD 183 when compared to USD 361 per vegetable farming 9. In the cocoa value chain more female farmers were reached through training, 40% in2019, compared to 20% in 2018. Households with both male and female memberstrained demonstrated an 18% higher cocoa yield compared to households with onlythe male participant trained. 10. GROW also took on a larger regulatory reform and industry engagement role, recognizing that in both the Cocoa and Vegetables sectors, new regulations could either significantly boost industry reform and the durability of the activities or break them. However, it should be noted that the discussion on regulatory reforms was done in collaboration with other development partners and together with them GROW contributed to changes benefiting the programme and target group. Additionally, toward the end of 2019, GROW also increased the activity to document and share program learning and to guide the Liberian development community toward a deeper appreciation of market-oriented initiatives, particularly with respect to the target sectors. GROW only promotes and facilitates training on organic cocoa production.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
